sections.title: Shrink Your Tax Bill the Smart Way
sections.subtitle: Identify deductions and credits you actually qualify for and stack them into a compliant filing strategy

sections.title: What You'll Work Through
items: Difference between above-the-line and itemized deductions
Key tax credits for families, education, and clean energy
How phase-outs, income limits, and carryforwards change the math
Building a documentation checklist so you can substantiate each benefit

sections.title: Deduction vs. Credit Deep Dive
sections.content: Deductions reduce taxable income, while credits reduce the tax owed dollar-for-dollar. Above-the-line deductions like HSA contributions or student loan interest apply before adjusted gross income, potentially unlocking more credits. Itemized deductions add up mortgage interest, charitable gifts, and state/local taxesâ€”evaluate whether they exceed the standard deduction before itemizing.

points.title: Child Tax Credit
points.description: Worth up to $2,000 per qualifying child, phasing out starting at $200,000 single/$400,000 married filing jointly.

points.title: Lifetime Learning Credit
points.description: Covers 20% of up to $10,000 in qualified education expenses each year, per return, with income phase-outs.

points.title: Clean Vehicle Credit
points.description: Worth up to $7,500 for eligible electric vehicles, but subject to MSRP caps, income limits, and final assembly rules.

sections.title: Stack Withholding Wisely
sections.content: Adjust Form W-4 or quarterly estimated payments after big deduction or credit changes so you keep cash flow aligned all year.

sections.title: Phase-Out Mechanics
sections.content: Credits and deductions often shrink as income rises. Use tax software or IRS worksheets to find the exact reduction rate. When phase-outs loom, consider timing income, deferring bonuses, or increasing retirement contributions to stay under thresholds.

sections.title: Benefit Maximizer Workshop
steps: List every deduction you used last year and categorize them as above-the-line or itemized.
Estimate current-year eligibility for credits (child, education, energy) using IRS screening tools.
Calculate whether bunching deductions (e.g., charitable giving) in one year beats the standard deduction.
Create a digital folder structure for receipts, 1098/1099 forms, and credit certifications.
Note any income phase-outs and design mitigation moves (retirement contributions, HSA funding, business expense timing).

sections.title: Document in Real Time
sections.content: Use a scanning app to capture receipts the day you incur an expense. Tag them with categories so filing season becomes a drag-and-drop exercise.
